metadata.title: "Fighting for Family Farms" - Rep. Ted Budd (R-NC-13)

sections: While the financial industry once kept a low profile in elections, it‚Äôs no secret which races it‚Äôs banking on winning this election cycle.

That‚Äôs because big banks aren‚Äôt shy about the fact that they‚Äôre using multiple political groups to run misleading ads and donate millions on behalf of key Republican and Democratic candidates they believe will help them slash regulations and preserve predatory practices. The fact that buttoned-up bankers are intervening so shamelessly on behalf of
and other right-wing demagogues might seem surprising ‚Äî but the in-your-face approach is exactly the point.

In the wake of the 2008 financial crisis, the industry was chafing under the yoke of modest regulations passed to try to avert another global catastrophe. It decided to regroup and embrace a new tack.
‚ÄúCongress isn‚Äôt afraid of bankers,‚Äù Roger Beverage, president and CEO of the Oklahoma Bankers Association,
. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt think we‚Äôll do anything to kick them out of office. We are trying to change that perception.‚Äù
To do so, Beverage joined with the heads of other state banking associations to launch
, a pro-deregulation industry group that rails against
for the competition they pose to ‚Äúcommunity banks.‚Äù
This election season, the group is also
its role in funneling cash into what it refers to on its website as the midterm‚Äôs ‚Äúthree most important races for bankers.‚Äù Those races are:
opponent of consumer protections and overtime pay
who initially threatened to vote down former President Donald Trump‚Äôs tax cuts because they weren‚Äôt generous enough
megacorporations that also happen to be his largest donors.
Johnson is attempting to fend off progressive challenger Mandela Barnes.
Rep. Randy Feenstra (R-Iowa), who, as a state representative, launched a crusade to
and, once he arrived in Washington, began pushing to
Republican Rep. Ted Budd, who‚Äôs making a gambit for an open North Carolina Senate seat after spending three terms
aiding predatory lenders trying to evade his own state‚Äôs laws
‚Äî developments that also happened to benefit his campaign donors.

In an informational video that opens against the backdrop of the Statue of Liberty, Friends of Traditional Banking describes how it bundles cash from donors nationwide and deploys it on behalf of a few endorsed candidates each cycle. The group is a super PAC, which means it can raise unlimited funds from individual and corporate donors.
So far this cycle, the self-proclaimed ‚Äútrue grassroots movement‚Äù has collected
from a broad coalition of banks, bankers, and banking associations, in addition to soliciting direct contributions to candidates from its more than 20,000 members.

‚ÄúOur unique approach is working,‚Äù the group says on its website. ‚ÄúSo far, we‚Äôve channeled $3,285,750 to key candidates resulting in victories in some of the closest races critical to banking.‚Äù
A Super PAC Of Their Own
Friends of Traditional Banking explains its origin story as a corrective to crushing over-regulation in the wake of the financial crisis.
‚ÄúPoliticians knew it was their bad housing policies that created the crisis,‚Äù
says another video on the group‚Äôs website.

‚ÄúIn order to deflect blame and get re-elected, they decided to blame the banks. They knew full well that traditional banks did not cause the crisis, but nonetheless, they adopted massive new regulations on traditional community banks.‚Äù
for independent expenditures for the 2012 elections, picking Elizabeth Warren‚Äôs Democratic Senate bid in Massachusetts as
one of its first two targets
. While that intervention failed, with Warren beating out Republican Scott Brown,
, former commercial banker Republican Dean Heller, won a Nevada Senate seat and soon joined the Banking Committee.
, according to its website, raising money for independent expenditures as well as delivering hundreds of thousands of dollars a piece to candidates in direct contributions from its ‚Äúfriends.‚Äù

The group has stuck to a steady tune amidst the larger drumbeat for deregulation, insisting that Main Street banks don‚Äôt ail from the ills of Wall Street and shouldn‚Äôt be subject to the same requirements. That refrain found a receptive audience in 2018, when corporate Democrats joined Republicans to pass a sweeping bank deregulation bill
in the name of providing relief for ‚Äúcommunity banks.‚Äù

This legislative coup led Friends of Traditional Banking to endorse its first Democrat, Montana Sen. Jon Tester in 2018, without whom ‚Äúregulatory reform would not have happened,‚Äù the group‚Äôs executive director, Mike Winder,
As predicted by opponents like Warren, the legislation did precisely the opposite of what its proponents claimed,
and further collapsing any distinction between ‚Äútraditional‚Äù and investment banks.

The financial industry has another weapon in its arsenal: the American Bankers Association, a lobbying group that represents some of the nation‚Äôs largest banks and has also taken an increasingly overt and aggressive stance in the electoral arena, running
on behalf of dozens of federal candidates.
In 2018, as Friends of Traditional Banking went to bat for Tester, the American Bankers Association‚Äôs political action committee (PAC) also ran its
on behalf of Tester and Budd. The move was part of an overhaul of the group‚Äôs political strategy,
, that also saw it hire the Chamber of Commerce‚Äôs former political director to serve as chief political strategist.
The American Bankers Association is registered as a
granted to business organizations devoted to promoting the common business interests of their members. While many of the
ads paid for by its PAC
focus on regulatory and economic issues,
created to boost Budd strayed further afield,
thanking the Senate candidate for his support for family farmers.
That‚Äôs an especially odd note for a bank lobbying group to strike, given Budd and his family‚Äôs role in a bankruptcy that resulted in millions of dollars of losses for farmers, according to the
